results.title: Bricks and mortar
results.creator_credit: Brian Bergin, Malcolm Smith and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Further Education”.
One of a series of films which deal with the idea that our education should not stop with the end of formal studies. Explains how and why sources are allocated for adult education in South Australia.

results.title: Bricks and mortar
results.creator_credit: Topical Film Company and Brent Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Brickwork”.
One of a series of 8 parts; the complete series gives a basic training in building construction with reference to brickwork. The film starts by describing classes of bricks; commons, facings, engineering, purpose-made, insulating and fire bricks, and deals with a number of varieties of individual types, their sizes and weights. The gauging of mortar is demonstrated. Hand and machine mixing and the pan mill are dealt with. The method of describing the thickness of walls in terms of brick lengths is explained.

results.title: Bricklaying : it's easier than you think
results.brief_description: This video is designed to teach the inexperienced handy person to completely undertake the building of simple brick structures. It emphasises the importance of using the correct tools and materials and demonstrates the methods and techniques employed by bricklayers to achieve good results for basic brick constructions.

results.title: Bribie
results.creator_credit: Kevin Brady, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Kevin Brady sets the record straight on the Battle of Bribie, considered to be the closest Australia got to losing a battle in Vietnam. His “digger’s account” illustrates the major obstacles and the bravery shown by the men, who were met with gunfire on landing.

results.title: Brian Wilson : I wasn't made for these times
results.creator_credit: Don Was, Larry Shapiro, Ken Kushnick, David Passick, Cro-Magnon Films and Palomar Pictures
results.brief_description: Even if you’re not a fan of the Beach Boys, “I Wasn’t Made for These Times” is a fascinating documentary for anyone interested in popular music and songwriting. Filmed in black and white, the film focuses on the life of Brian Wilson and on his contributions as a composer rather than on the turbulent history of the Beach Boys. Intercutting present day footage of Wilson performing in the studio with interviews with his family and himself, Brian Wilson’s life makes compelling viewing. Interviews with musicians such as Tom Petty, Lindsay Buckingham, Linda Ronsdtadt, John Cale, David Crosby and Graham Nash demonstrate the far reaching influence that Brian Wilson had on rock music.

results.title: Brewing up a fairytale
results.creator_credit: Christine Evely and Glenferrie Primary School
results.brief_description: From the ACMI Primary School Program “Brewing up a new Tale: a live action production workshop” for lower primary. Students interact with Green Screen Technology and fairytale sets to learn the basics of narrative contruction, genre and and scene.

results.title: Brett Whiteley: Alchemy
results.brief_description: A study of the work, philosophy and artistic process of renowned Australian painter, Brett Whiteley, as he prepares for and then exhibits the extensive panel work, “Alchemy”. The program is also integrated with a discussion of the history and mythology of alchemy in the ancient world and of the practices and beliefs of alchemists which weaves, in an explanatory and complementary way, through the coverage of Whiteley as he paints and discusses his work. Whiteley’s sense of producing different languages in painting, of shifting away from Australian naturalism to seek a balance between the natural and the surreal, is evoked insightfully in the program through the extensive interviews and commentary from Whiteley himself, the view of the artist at work in his studio, and through the thread of the study of alchemy. Along with Whiteley’s comments on his personal philosophies, the focus of the discussion delves into his fascinations and experiences, expressed through the form of his paintings, in terms of the alchemist notion of transmutation, and the ideal of a journey towards bursting through the boundary to dreams. This is exemplified in the work “Alchemy”, where the mind on its meanders, an order lost in detail and an eye to the spiritual is presented in the form of a paneled mural. The program contains footage of the opening of the exhibition of this work with its reception analysed through interviews and sound bytes of Whiteley’s colleagues, friends and family, art critics and curators, providing a close to this meditative outline of Brett Whiteley’s artistic process from original concept to exhibition.
